qas.question: When will a person or animal lose consciousness  when exposed to a vacuum?
A shuttle astronauts prevents ebullism at 2 kPa with what item?
What is the forming of gas bubbles in body fluids at a lowered pressure called?
What prevents body rupture at low altitude when human body is bloated by gas bubbles?
At what temperature does frost usually occur in space?
When exposed to frost who will die from ebullism within minutes?
What will frost cause in body fluids at reduced pressures?
What can a person wear to prevent frost on the skin?
What does a CAPS suit prevent frost at pressures as low as?

context: <b5_0>Humans and animals<b5_0/> exposed to vacuum will lose consciousness <a0_0>after a few seconds<a0_0/> and die of hypoxia within minutes, but the symptoms are not nearly as graphic as commonly depicted in media and popular culture. The reduction in pressure lowers the temperature at which blood and other body fluids boil, but the elastic pressure of blood vessels ensures that this boiling point remains above the internal body temperature of <b4_0>37 °C<b4_0/>. Although the blood will not boil, the formation of <b6_0>gas bubbles<b6_0/> in bodily fluids at reduced pressures, known as ebullism, is still a concern. The gas may bloat the body to twice its normal size and slow circulation, but <a3_0>tissues are elastic and porous<a3_0/> enough to prevent rupture. Swelling and <a2_0>ebullism<a2_0/> can be restrained by containment in <b7_0>a flight suit<b7_0/>. Shuttle astronauts wore a fitted elastic garment called <a1_0>the Crew Altitude Protection Suit (CAPS)<a1_0/> which prevents ebullism at pressures as low as <b8_0>2 kPa (15 Torr)<b8_0/>. Rapid boiling will cool the skin and create frost, particularly in the mouth, but this is not a significant hazard.
